title: Father-of-two Darrin Barnett says climate protests do more harm than good
text:
My primary school aged daughter took part in the recent school strike for climate but so-called climate rebellion protesters who disrupted traffic in Brisbane this week don’t speak for her.

A somewhat precocious six-year-old, she asked to attend and I said: 'Yes' – not because I want her to be brainwashed but because I want her to learn to think for herself.

My son, 9, had the option to attend the rally but chose to stay at school to play basketball, and that’s fine too.

Both of the School Strikes 4 Climate in Sydney this year have been peaceful events, with a positive community feel.

Darrin Barnett and his six-year-old daughter (pictured together) attended a climate change rally earlier this year

Children skipped class to attend rallies across the globe last week, inspired by Greta Thunberg

Indeed, all of the police I interacted with used it as an opportunity to engage with kids in a very helpful and positive way in what effectively became a community relations exercise.

My daughter loved the colour and movement, enjoyed the fact that many of her classmates were there, and asked a very sensible set of questions.

What is climate change?

What causes it?

Can we do anything about it?

Who wants to stop us acting and why?

A climate change protester in Brisbane is arrested after disrupting city streets. More action is planned across the country

Protesters hit the street of Melbourne in a series of planned events across the country. Events will take place throughout the week from Brisbane to Adelaide

I replied to the best of my knowledge; that almost all scientists say the earth is getting hotter and this means we that we not only get more warm weather but it alters the natural balance and we are seeing more floods, fires and droughts in many parts of the world.

It could be caused by many things but that having so many people using so many things has consequences for a planet that can’t grow any bigger like the global population does.

Some politicians, people who make money out of the way we currently do things and a bunch of grumpy older people who don’t like being told they are wrong refuse to change their ways.

An activist is arrested during an Extinction Rebellion climate protest in Melbourne

But it’s also true that in Australia, we have the most comfortable lifestyle in the world and this happens in large part due to digging things out of the ground – such as coal and iron ore – and selling them to people who don’t have those resources in their own country.

So we can’t move too quickly or everyone will get scared or resent being told what to do. Then nothing will change.

That’s why it was so frustrating to see protesters chaining themselves by their necks to barricades in the Brisbane CBD this week as part of the so-called climate rebellion.

The arrogance of interrupting the lives of everyday people to press home a political point is as short sighted as it is foolish.

This doesn’t help pressure governments to act on climate action as it puts reasonable people offside, including many who might broadly agree.

Climate change protestors from the Extinction Rebellion movement gather to demonstrate at Town Hall in Sydney

Deliberately inflammatory language that protesters will occupy hundreds of cities all over the globe until their demands are met to stop the climate catastrophe amounts to little more than bullying.

Trying to apply pressure without strategy rarely amounts to anything and it is interesting that even the protesters agree they are exercising their “privilege” to participate in civil disobedience.

It’s a privilege the Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton says might be severely curtailed, suggesting naming and shaming, jail time and even stopping welfare payments to protesters.

Painting climate protesters as layabouts, criminals and welfare cheats serves a political purpose because it pushes them and to some extent their ideas, to the fringes of the debate.

Police officers drag activists from Extinction Rebellion out of the road in Elizabeth Street as they attempted to block traffic during a protest in Sydney

Looking like the sensible grown-up in an argument means you can occupy the middle ground. That’s where a majority of public opinion sits and elections are won.

There are certainly a number of climate deniers in the Morrison Government but there are many, many more that will be happy to ride the politics to the line.

That’s why Prime Minister Scott Morrison’s response to teenage Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg’s speech at the United Nations as subjecting Australian children to “needless anxiety” was clever.

While the Prime Minister says he wants to give wants to give Australian children confidence they will have an “economy to live in”, the kids themselves are entirely justified in arguing that they need confidence there will be a planet to live on.

You can also expect Labor to sit in the centre on this issue, with Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese supporting new legislation to stop animal rights activists targeting farms, warning vegan terrorists are not a Labor constituency.

The climate wars won’t be ending anytime soon but one thing I can say is this: Barricading yourself on city streets for climate action will do nothing but give an advantage to your opponents. Even a six-year-old can tell you that.
description: Darrin Barnett, who has worked within the Australian political sphere, says he wouldn't oppose his children attending peaceful climate rallies. But some, he says, do more harm than good.
authors: Darrin Barnett For Daily Mail Australia
